notes: While criticizing Israel's crackdown on demonstrators in its occupied territories, Arab leaders still favor negotiations with the state in an international peace conference, Rep. John Kasich (R-12) said Tuesday after returning from an 11-day trip to the Middle East. Leaders in Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Egypt ‘all communicated the same message: that moderate Arab leaders have risen in stature, that they want an international peace conference,’ Kasich said. ‘They want to negotiate with Israel, but they want the United States to be more supportive’ of the idea, the congressman added.

A 19-member U.S. delegation selected by President Reagan is heading to El Salvador this weekend to monitor legislative and municipal elections that leftist guerrillas have threatened to disrupt with violence, officials said Friday…The delegation will be briefed by State Department officials in San Salvador before monitoring the elections. Additional members of Congress in the delegation are Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo.; Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla.; Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio; Rep. Beverly Byron, D-Md.; and Rep. Alan Mollohan, D-W. Va

Many other Ohio lawmakers are visiting exotic locations as well. Rep. Donald E. ‘Buz’ Lukens, R-Middletown, one of the state's most globe-trotting congressmen, will be spending part of his break visiting Cyprus, Greece and Malta. Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Navarre, is on a Pentagon-sponsored tour of European cities and Rep. John Kasich, R-Westerville, is on a privately-sponsored tour of Africa and Ireland to study energy issues.

Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, says Soviets bugged the airplanes, buses and hotel rooms they provided for a congressional delegation on a 13-day visit to the Soviet Union. Kasich said he and 11 other members of Congress were warned by U.S. advisers not to discuss classified information with each other at any point during the trip because of bugs. The delegation, which included Reps. Les Aspin, D-Wis., and Bill Dickinson, R-Ala., chairman and ranking minority member respectively of the House Armed Services Committee, made the trip mainly to make contact with their Soviet counterparts. They returned to the United States last Friday.

Twelve members of the House of Representatives have gone to Kuwait on a visit whose financing has raised questions among the House leadership…The group left Wednesday night and is scheduled to return on Sunday…The two Democrats on the trip are Charles Luken of Ohio and Pete Geren of Texas. The other Republicans are Robert K. Dornan of California, Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania, John R. Kasich of Ohio, Helen Delich Bentley of Maryland, Bill Paxon of New York, Ronald K. Machtley of Rhode Island, Michael G. Oxley of Ohio, Chalmers P. Wylie of Ohio and James Inhofe of Oklahoma.

Rep. John R. Kasich leaves today for a weeklong congressional tour of South and Central America. The delegation, led by Sen. Richard G. Lugar, R-Ind., will travel to Uruguay, Brazil, Chile, Nicaragua and El Salvador. Lugar's invitation to Kasich, R-Ohio (Westerville), arose from the fact both observed the 1988 elections in El Salvador. This is Kasich's first congressional trip to South America.

Much of Bosnia resembles scenes from World War II, U.S. Rep. John R. Kasich said yesterday. 'There are buildings exploded all over the place. Pockmarks from the gunfire. They have trouble with mines everywhere - it's just a lot of rubble,' the Republican from Westerville said. Kasich spoke with reporters in Columbus just hours after returning from a whirlwind trip with President Clinton and other dignitaries to assess Bosnian politics and bolster the morale of U.S.  troops there. Clinton, who announced earlier the troops would stay 'indefinitely' beyond the original June 30 deadline, organized the 36-hour trip that included a bipartisan delegation of 11 members of Congress; Secretary of State Madeline Albright; former Sen. Bob Dole, the Republican who ran against Clinton; Dole's wife, Elizabeth, the president of the American Red Cross; and the president's wife, Hillary, and daughter, Chelsea.
